Thanks for your kindness, but, well, I actually know what these 
parameters=
 mean, but *don't* know how to decide the parameter values 
in a specific p=
roblem. I noticed that in different experiments there 
are different parame=
ter values, but I don't know why, though they are 
found experimentally, th=
ere should be something that tells you the 
range of a parameter in a certa=
in experiment. 
Back to my problem, I used the same parameter setting as DP=
M, but 
could not get a satisfied answer, and I thought the output I need w=
as 
similar to DPM. Could you tell me why? I had not expected that you 
wou=
ld reply so fast, morning.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski"=
 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Well basically you need to understand h=
ow two genotypes (NNs) are 
> compared so that it is determined whether the=
y are in the same 
> species or not. 
> The total number of excess and disj=
oint genes is counted, as well 
as 
> the average weight difference of matc=
hing genes. These 3 values are 
> then multiplied by their importance facto=
rs and summed up to 
produce 
> the distance value. If that distance value =
is less than the 
> compatibility threshold, then the genotypes are in the =
same 
species, 
> else they are in two separate species.
> So what you need=
 to adjust is the importance factors and the 
> compatibility threshold. 
>=
 There is no general rule on how to adjust the importance factors, 
but 
> =
notice that if you set them all to 1.0, this basically means that a 
> weig=
ht difference of 1.0 is as important as one excess or one 
> disjoint gene.=
 (I assume that the numbers of excess/disjoint genes 
> are absolute, they =
are not divided by genome size). 
> You can also make the compatibility tre=
shold dynamic, that is, 
choose 
> a target number of species and alter the=
 compatibility threshold 
each 
> generation, if there are too many species=
, raise it, or lower it if 
> there are too few.
